If you run it with a "-clean" ones is the going to problem disappear?

As you mentioned, what you see seems like the registry cache gone wrong. The "-clean" will force Eclipse to recreate cached information.

The problem is not widespread; in a year I this is only a second mention of it. The first one appeared after upgrade from an earlier version and was non-reproducible. Unless there are steps to reproduce cache corruption, we can't do much about it, so I'll close this bug for now. Please re-open if it is reproducible or happens often.

Also I can't pass a chance to suggest upgrading to a current version of Eclipse :-).
Sorry, the first line should have been:

Could you run Eclipse with a "-clean" option one time and see if Eclipse is going to start properly after that?

(For some reason Bugzilla really takes away my grammar skills. And they never been great to beging with :-).)
